13 episodes of this anime didn't give this anime justice. The story was pacing well until it gets to one of the middle episodes. It returns to regular pacing until towards the end. Everything is rushed and you weren't given enough time to process what was going on. They had trivial stuff in the anime that I felt were teasers, as if they were going to have a back story or explanation them, but none at all. The main character was also VERY stereotypical MC at the very end. The concept of this anime wasn't widened out enough for us to call it a great,but probably the manga has an answer for that. If this was a 24 episode series, then maybe the reception would've been a lot better.

The story drags itself. Characters that seem to be essential to the plot just disapear in the middle of the story, like Hunter John Doe and his cats and even the main vilain! The side stories of the suport characters are left mostly untouched and are boring. The main characters don't evolve, don't learn anything from previous encounters with other enemies, and at a certain point the heroin is able to performe a mysterious and awesome atack, only to have it never used or even mencioned again!
Also, the setting of a dream is poorly explored. The art of the characters are fine, but the backgroundis inexpressive. They could have made it awesome and beautiful, even surreal. Instead, the scenery is static, mostly unchangeable, like a fighting game background.

Yumekui Merry, this was one interesting anime. All about those dreams and a mission set forth by our protag. Basically setting up a 2 world system, the real one and the dream one. But let me break down the categories that I can set this anime in and telling you my side of things.
Action. This is a action anime. There is some type of action conflict that arises in every single episode. The beginning was fairly good and tied in some of the major points of this anime together but you have to really focus a bit to understand what is going on for thefirst two episodes.


Supernatural. Dream demons are the things in this anime that take hold of humans to make them their vessels. So needless to say, it is supernatural. I don't think I should go any further into it than that.


On a side note, some parts of the anime reminded of some romance but it is not the main focus so really should not pay much attention to it.


Overall this anime is good but it is not great. I wish that they would not rush things too hastily but I feel like they did a bit but I think the overall score of this anime is good. I wouldn't recommend this anime to anyone who is just starting to get into anime for it might be hard to follow sometimes and this is not the greatest anime out there. For those who like action and supernatural, this is up your alley. You will enjoy this anime but not really love it. If you have time, watch this anime, but if you have other priorities like some other anime, then go watch those.


Sorry, no witty comments in this review. See you next time.

Story: The concept of dream and dream demons was very interesting. I liked the idea and adding a cute heroine definitely made things better. However, it just didn't deliver as well as I would have liked. They had a good thing going but the ending felt so complete. They added all these undeveloped bits that I wonder why they added them in the first. What was the point of mentioning the romance or introducing certain ideas if they won't be carried out? The ending was mediocre at best leaving many unanswered questions. It had good ideas and theme along with some cuteness and humour butthat wasn't enough. The series is short and is easy to go through so it didn't feel like a complete waste of time. However, it was definitely disappointing.


Animation: It was alright. The character designs were all pretty and attractive; however, Merry was the only memorable one. The real world was nicely animated but the dream world fell short to me. The dream world were lackluster and bland when it could have been much more. The action scenes were disappointing as they were very choppy. However, for the most part, the animation was pretty and they gave enough fan service without being ecchi or overdoing it.


Sound: I really liked the opening. I actually liked the opening more than the series itself. However, the rest of the music was subpar. The soundtrack varied from generic gamer music to woodwinds. Although it wasn't bad, it was strange. The ending was ok and catchy but generic. I probably won't remember it in a while. The seiyuus did a good job though,


Characters: Good ideas without enough to flesh them out. Like the plot, they started out well but didn't have adequete development or background. There were parts of them that were introduced but were never fully explained. However, for the most part, they were cute and likable.


Overall: Good idea but disappointing. It will start out fun but leaving you unsatisfied....

The initial idea that is introduced to you in the first episode is amazing. The magic of a world of dreams and creatures that hope to have a place in reality is quite intriguing and interesting. A Main character that's stuck in the real world without knowing why nor remembering how she got there in the first place gives you something to look after during the development of the series. And the needed male main character with unusual powers for a human (btw, he reminded me AWFULLY a lot of Yuuji from Shakugan no Shana). A very interesting idea, so I was happy with howit started.


But then, I found myself utterly disappointed. The plot just... shattered down. Nothing made sense anymore, and the characters introduced later were lame and unneeded. I have to admit I was excited by Kawanami, but only because of my fangirling about a possible Yuri development with Isami... so it doesn't really count. But what was her purpose, really? Just so they could introduce a mildly cool Dream Demon?


Mistletine. I loved her when she first appeared. The usually cruel and merciless villian, which is also a lolita. I always love that kind of characters. But... seriously? What the hell happened in the 12th episode? So Imma jump here, dodge there, evil laugh here, evil joke there, then I'm gone... EVEN THOUGH I'M KICKING THE GOOD GUY'S ASSES. No, I'm gone, bai bai. I can't finish these guys up since it's not the final episode (as one of the reviewers said already). It's the worse episode ever. Or so I thought, until I watched the final episode.


Worst. Ending. Ever.


The battle sequence during the episode was lame and boring. How she was killed was boring. The Power of the Dream is the Power of the Will... seriously? Seriously? (or something like that) They could've done a lot more with that battle. How come Merry vs Play was more interesting than the final battle? And once everything is over... what happened to the teacher? And what happened to the Ercles (Hercules?) Pharos? I was hoping they were going to fight against him, or is there a second season? Because that would be the ONLY explanation to have such a bad ending for an anime, though that's not a valid excuse anyway.


Also, where the hell did John Doe went? He was, by far, the coolest Dream Demon in the whole series. They had so many elements to work with and made an amazing anime, and yet they just delivered a half-hearted effort of an anime.


Aside from the Poor plot and mediocre character development, everything else was okay. The art was fantastic, wasn't expecting less from JCStaff since I'm a huge fan of them (Shana, Kaichou wa maid-sama, Ookami-san, Zakuro, Railgun, Majutsu no Index, etc), though it dropped a bit when the plot started being nonexistent, but still it was great.


And on a final note. WTF Yui? Air Trombone? Wuuuut?

I was inspired to write this review by bad press this show is getting on the web.  Well, okay, more like random idiots badmouthing it.  That’s how the Internet is.  Anyway, I don’t think this show is as bad as some have made it out to be.  In fact, I would even go as far as calling it good. 
The strength of Yumekui Merry is in creating mood.  In particular all the freaky dream sequences, which are helped in no small part by the music.  The characters are intricate and their interactions maintain sufficient complexity for an enjoyable watch(assuming you like your villains so thoroughly despicable). \n\n
Unfortunately, complexity is also the show’s weakness.  It never really decides what it wants to be.  Throughout its run, the show attempts to weave together so many diverse elements that, instead of a tapestry, it winds up with a tangled mess of yarn that may leave you vaguely hoping for a second season to tie up some of the loose ends.

I had randomly found this show and decided why not. I ended up finishing it one night. It had a great story, great charecters, and looked amazing. I enjoyed it until the last episode where at it just ends. I was not to happy. I found the manga and the two are not the same. the anime varies from the manga. In all truth the manga was way better.

Yumekui Merry had introduced an amazing concept,the idea of beings that inhabit the dreams of others and a world of dreams. The anime had great music as well as great animation. in the story department , however, the anime was lacking a lot. The fight scenes were decent when they could have been phenomenal and the story was okay when it should have been great. if you are into anime and are looking for something new that looks good and has an ok story than u should watch this. However, if you are like me and are not just looking for an anime but forsomething with a great story as well then u should give up on the anime and read the manga instead, its much better.

In a way, it sort of hurts to give this just a 6. The concept seemed really good, and there was a lot of potential to develop the characters, the story, and anything else. I guess it's a pitfall of manga conversions, but I haven't been this disappointed since Pandora Hearts at the lack of closure. The anime ends in the wrong place, with closure of one plot point, but no closure to the biggest questions, leaving it essentially unfinished.
By the 13th episode the characters had hardly left the molds of their stereotypes, and that was another big strike against. It seemed there was alot happening "off camera" between some characters, while others basically dropped out, and the main characters said pretty much the lines I imagined would be the defaults if this anime was made with a drag-and-drop tool.\n\n
I do give it high marks for the art and sound quality, though, but there are plenty of good-looking, good-sounding shows out there that are at the least complete.
